msDesc.head:
Letter from
Maria Edgeworth
to [Unknown], , May 1, 1824

editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in a manuscript. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

revisionDesc.change: Created file for letter, encoded letter

div.p:
I have been very negligent
but not quite so ungrateful
as I may have appeared
to M. de la Grange - I long
delayed to thank him for
a most agreeable letter
but I have within the last
two months written to him
to return him my thanks
for his attentions to an
American gentleman
Mr. Ralstone to whom I
gave an introduction to
him about two years ago
- Mr. Ralstone wrote after
his return to America to express his gratitude
for the Spanish introductions
which he obtained

from the friend to whom I
had introduced him at
Paris - Though he did not
name M. de la Grange
I am persuaded that you
were the person who furnished
him with letters to Spain
which were of the greatest
service. - I assure you that
I was sufficiently ashamed
of my procrastination when
I received his letter telling
me how kindly you had
honored my recommenda
=tionrecommendation & I wrote directly to
thank you - but I have lately
learned that this letter and
a packet containing letters
from me to our friends the
Deleperts and our friends the
Creeds never reached Paris

You will I am sure believe
that this is the plain truth

Permit me then to
present to you one of our
most intimate & I think I
may say agreeable friends
- Mr. Strickland - a name
not so revolting to French
pronunciation as Edge-
worth - but as you mastered
that Strickland will only
be too easy for you - Mr. Strick
landStrickland who has the adminis
=trationadministration of a large estate in
Ireland gives himself a
few weeks holidays from
business to refresh himself
with travelling & with seeing
Paris - Paris is not new
to him; but there is always
something new to every
man of sense and taste in
your splendid capital -
No one can do its honours
better than M. Edouard
de la Grange; and I beg

the favor of him to let Mr. Strick
landStrickland have as much of his
assistance & time as he can
spare - Mr. S - loves walking
- riding - driving & conversation
- Reading - painting - music
- nothing is indifferent to
him that can interest a
well informed & well bred
gentleman. - He speaks
French easily & will con-
verseconverse with you in whichever
language you please. -
He is 1 one of our- first Catho
licCatholic families - I cannot
vouch for his being dans
les bons principes in a
certain exclusive sense of the
word; but I think that you
& he will agree well.

He will tell you every
thing of us that you can
wish to hear. Especially that

that we retain the most & agreeable
remembrance of our residence
in Paris and of all our French
friends - The very pleasant
hours you gave us & our
conversations in the car
riagecarriage where we discussed
so many points, sentimental
literary and Metaphysical
and we all have agreed
in recolelcting with
peculiar pleasure - In
deed a good easy coach
I consider as better than
any salon for conversa
=tionconversation because one is not
subject to the perpetual change
& interruptions to which good
breeding subjects us in the
salon. The motto of sallonsalon
conversation must ever be

But I like not to slide
over things so very rapidly
as to have no time or possibili
typossibility for understanding them

- Do you still retain your
taste for metaphysics?
and have you advanced
many paces?- I can never
touch upon that subject
without fresh admiration
of the good humor with
which you used to endure
my persiflage. We have
no English word which
exactly translates persiflage
- Quizzing - besides being
too vulgar does not give
the idea justly by any
means - bantering is odious
& belongs now only to old
plays - Shewing a person
up is still more odious
though fashionable - It is
far very far from my idea
of persiflage - irony or
raillery come nearest but
there are many shades
between this & the French
- Ironic raillery might do

for want of better - but still
it does but badly - You
must be a perfect Englishman
or understand English as
well as you do French if
you seize all these shades
& comprehend my last
page - If you do not understand
"Glissez mortel n'appuyez pas"

You are in the intimate
society of Madame de Duras
- Among my regrets in
leaving Paris was a strong
regret that I had not been
able to become better ac
quaintedacquainted with her. I hear
much of certain novels of
hers which are printed
but not published - Given
to her friends but not to
the public - It would gratify
me in every way extremely
if you could procure for
me a copy. - My friend
Mr. Strickland would

My sisters desire to be
kindly remembered to
you - Mrs. Edgeworth &
my brother desire me to
tell you that they hope
you will some time trav
veltravel to this remote Ireland
and that we may have
the pleasure of seeing you
at Edgeworths Town - In
this hope.
div.closer:
- Adieu for the present
Maria Edgeworth -
